member.name: Windows.Animate_Close
member.summary: Closes an AVI clip. You can use this macro or send the ACM_OPEN message explicitly, passing in NULL parameters.
member.param: A handle to the animation control.

member.name: Windows.Animate_Create
member.summary: Creates an animation control. Animate_Create calls the function to create the animation control.
member.param: A handle to the parent window.
The child window identifier of the animation control.
The window styles. For a list of the animation control style values, see Animation Control Styles.
A handle to the instance of the module that is creating the animation control.

member.name: Windows.Animate_IsPlaying
member.summary: Checks to see if an Audio-Video Interleaved (AVI) clip is playing. You can use this macro or send an ACM_ISPLAYING message.
member.param: A handle to the animation control.

member.name: Windows.Animate_Open
member.summary: Opens an AVI clip and displays its first frame in an animation control. You can use this macro or send the ACM_OPEN message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the animation control.

param.name: szName
param.para: A pointer to a buffer that contains the path of the AVI file or the name of an AVI resource. Alternatively, this parameter can consist of the AVI resource identifier in the LOWORD and zero in the HIWORD. To create this value, use the macro. The control loads an AVI resource from the module specified by the instance handle passed to the function, the macro, or the dialog box creation function that created the control. The AVI file or resource specified by lpszName must not contain audio.
If this parameter is NULL, the system closes the AVI file that was previously opened for the specified animation control, if any.

member.name: Windows.Animate_OpenEx
member.summary: Opens an AVI clip from a resource in a specified module and displays its first frame in an animation control. You can use this macro or send the ACM_OPEN message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the animation control.
An instance handle to the module from which the resource should be loaded. If this value is NULL, the resource is loaded from the module that created the animation control.

param.name: szName
param.para: A pointer to a buffer that contains the path of the AVI file or the name of an AVI resource. Alternatively, this parameter can consist of the AVI resource identifier in the LOWORD and zero in the HIWORD. To create this value, use the macro. The control loads the AVI resource from the module specified by hinst. The AVI file or resource specified by lpszName must not contain audio.
If this parameter is NULL, the system closes the AVI file that was previously opened for the specified animation control, if any.

member.name: Windows.Animate_Play
member.summary: Plays an AVI clip in an animation control. The control plays the clip in the background while the thread continues executing. You can use this macro or send the ACM_PLAY message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the animation control in which to play the AVI clip.
The zero-based index of the frame where playing begins. The value must be less than 65,536. A value of zero means begin with the first frame in the AVI clip.
The zero-based index of the frame where playing ends. The value must be less than 65,536. A value of -1 means end with the last frame in the AVI clip.
The number of times to replay the AVI clip. A value of -1 means replay the clip indefinitely.

member.name: Windows.Animate_Seek
member.summary: Directs an animation control to display a particular frame of an AVI clip. The control displays the clip in the background while the thread continues executing. You can use this macro or send the ACM_PLAY message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the animation control in which to display the AVI frame.
The zero-based index of the frame to display.

member.name: Windows.Animate_Stop
member.summary: Stops playing an AVI clip in an animation control. You can use this macro or send the ACM_STOP message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the animation control.

member.name: Windows.Button_GetIdealSize
member.summary: Gets the size of the button that best fits the text and image, if an image list is present. You can use this macro or send the BCM_GETIDEALSIZE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.
A pointer to a structure that receives the desired size of the button including the text and image list if present.

member.name: Windows.Button_GetImageList
member.summary: Gets the structure that describes the image list that is set for a button control. You can use this macro or send the BCM_GETIMAGELIST message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.
A pointer to a structure that contains image list information.

member.name: Windows.Button_GetNote
member.summary: Gets the text of the note associated with a command link button. You can use this macro or send the BCM_GETNOTE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.
A pointer to a null-terminated, Unicode string that contains the note.
A pointer to the length of the note, in characters.

member.name: Windows.Button_GetNoteLength
member.summary: Gets the length of the note text that may be displayed in the description for a command link. Use this macro or send the BCM_GETNOTELENGTH message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.

member.name: Windows.Button_GetSplitInfo
member.summary: Gets information for a specified split button control. Use this macro or send the BCM_GETSPLITINFO message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.

A pointer to a structure to receive information on the button specified by hwnd. The calling application is responsible for allocating the memory for the structure. Set the mask member of this structure to determine what information to receive.

member.name: Windows.Button_GetTextMargin
member.summary: Gets the margins used to draw text in a button control. You can use this macro or send the BCM_GETTEXTMARGIN message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.
A pointer to a structure that specifies the margins to use for drawing text in a button control.

member.name: Windows.Button_SetDropDownState
member.summary: Sets the drop down state for a specified button with style of BS_SPLITBUTTON. Use this macro or send the BCM_SETDROPDOWNSTATE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.
TRUE for state of BST_DROPDOWNPUSHED, or FALSE otherwise.

member.name: Windows.Button_SetElevationRequiredState
member.summary: Sets the elevation required state for a specified button or command link to display an elevated icon. Use this macro or send the BCM_SETSHIELD message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.
TRUE to draw an elevated icon, or FALSE otherwise.

member.name: Windows.Button_SetImageList
member.summary: Assigns an image list to a button control. You can use this macro or send the BCM_SETIMAGELIST message explicitly.

member.name: Windows.Button_SetNote

member.name: Windows.Button_SetSplitInfo
member.summary: Sets information for a specified split button control. Use this macro or send the BCM_SETSPLITINFO message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.

A pointer to a structure. The calling application is responsible for allocating the memory for this structure and initializing it. Set the mask member of this structure to determine what information to set for the button specified by hwnd.

member.name: Windows.Button_SetTextMargin
member.summary: Sets the margins for drawing text in a button control. You can use this macro or send the BCM_SETTEXTMARGIN message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the button control.
A pointer to a structure that specifies the margins to set for drawing text in a button control.

member.name: Windows.ComboBox_GetCueBannerText
member.summary: Gets the cue banner text displayed in the edit control of a combo box. Use this macro or send the CB_GETCUEBANNER message explicitly.

A pointer to a Unicode string buffer that receives the cue banner text. The calling application is responsible for allocating the memory for the buffer. The buffer size must be equal to the length of the cue banner string in WCHARs, plus 1—for the terminating NULL WCHAR.
The size of the buffer pointed to by lpwText in WCHARs.

member.name: Windows.ComboBox_SetMinVisible

member.param: The combo box.

member.name: Windows.CreateMappedBitmap
member.summary: Creates a bitmap for use in a toolbar.
member.param: Handle to the module instance with the executable file that contains the bitmap resource.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Uses a bitmap as a mask.

member.name: Windows.CreateStatusWindow

summary.para: Creates a status window, which is typically used to display the status of an application. The window generally appears at the bottom of the parent window, and it contains the specified text.
summary.div: Note This function is obsolete. Use instead.

member.param: Window styles for the status window. This parameter must include the WS_CHILD style and should also include the WS_VISIBLE style.
Pointer to a null-terminated string that specifies the status text for the first part.
handle to the parent window.
Control identifier for the status window. The window procedure uses this value to identify messages it sends to the parent window.
member.returns: Returns the handle to the status window if successful, or NULL otherwise. To retrieve extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.CreateToolbarEx

summary.para: Creates a toolbar window and adds the specified buttons to the toolbar.
summary.div: Note This function is deprecated, because it does not support all features of toolbars. Use instead. For examples, see Using Toolbar Controls.

member.param: Handle to the parent window for the toolbar.
Window styles for the toolbar. The WS_CHILD style is included by default. This parameter can also include a combination of styles as discussed in Toolbar Control and Button Styles.
Control identifier for the toolbar.
Number of button images contained in the bitmap specified byhBMInst andwBMID.
Module instance with the executable file that contains the bitmap resource.
Resource identifier for the bitmap resource. IfhBMInst is NULL, this parameter must be a valid bitmap handle.
Pointer to an array of structures that contain information about the buttons to add to the toolbar.
Number of buttons to add to the toolbar.
Width, in pixels, of the buttons to add to the toolbar.
Height, in pixels, of the buttons to add to the toolbar.
Width, in pixels, of the button images to add to the buttons in the toolbar.
Height, in pixels, of the button images to add to the buttons in the toolbar.
Size of a structure.
member.returns: Returns the window handle to the toolbar if successful, or NULL otherwise. To retrieve extended error information, call .

member.name: Windows.CreateUpDownControl
member.summary: Creates an up-down control. Note: This function is obsolete. It is a 16 bit function and cannot handle 32 bit values for range and position.
member.param: Window styles for the control. This parameter should include the WS_CHILD, WS_BORDER, and WS_VISIBLE styles, and it may include any of the window styles specific to the up-down control.
Horizontal coordinate, in client coordinates, of the upper-left corner of the control.
Vertical coordinate, in client coordinates, of the upper-left corner of the control.
Width, in pixels, of the up-down control.
Height, in pixels, of the up-down control.
Handle to the parent window of the up-down control.
Identifier for the up-down control.
Handle to the module instance of the application creating the up-down control.
Handle to the window associated with the up-down control. If this parameter is NULL, the control has no buddy window.
Upper limit (range) of the up-down control.
Lower limit (range) of the up-down control.
Position of the control.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the window handle to the up-down control. If the function fails, the return value is NULL.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_CloseMonthCal
member.summary: Closes the date and time picker (DTP) control. Use this macro or send the DTM_CLOSEMONTHCAL message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the DTP control.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_GetDateTimePickerInfo
member.summary: Gets information for a specified date and time picker (DTP) control.
member.param: A handle to the DTP control.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_GetIdealSize
member.summary: Gets the size needed to display the control without clipping. Use this macro or send the DTM_GETIDEALSIZE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the DTP control.
A pointer to a structure to receive the size. The caller is responsible for allocating this structure.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_GetMonthCal
member.summary: Gets the handle to a date and time picker's (DTP) child month calendar control. You can use this macro or send the DTM_GETMONTHCAL message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_GetMonthCalColor
member.summary: Gets the color for a given portion of the month calendar within a date and time picker (DTP) control. You can use this macro or send the DTM_GETMCCOLOR message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.

param.name: iColor
param.para: A value of type int specifying which month calendar color to retrieve. This value can be one of the following.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Retrieve the background color displayed between months.
Retrieve the background color displayed within the month.
Retrieve the color used to display text within a month.
Retrieve the background color displayed in the calendar's title.
Retrieve the color used to display text within the calendar's title.
Retrieve the color used to display header day and trailing day text. Header and trailing days are the days from the previous and following months that appear on the current month calendar.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_GetMonthCalFont
member.summary: Gets the font that the date and time picker (DTP) control's child month calendar control is currently using. You can use this macro or send the DTM_GETMCFONT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_GetMonthCalStyle
member.summary: Gets the style of a specified date and time picker (DTP) control. Use this macro or send the DTM_GETMCSTYLE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the DTP control.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_GetRange
member.summary: Gets the current minimum and maximum allowable system times for a date and time picker (DTP) control. You can use this macro, or send the DTM_GETRANGE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.
A pointer to a two-element array of structures.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_GetSystemtime
member.summary: Gets the currently selected time from a date and time picker (DTP) control and places it in a specified structure. You can use this macro, or send the DTM_GETSYSTEMTIME message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.

A pointer to a structure. If DTM_GETSYSTEMTIME returns GDT_VALID, this structure will contain the currently selected time. Otherwise, it will not contain valid information. This parameter must be a valid pointer; it cannot be NULL.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_SetFormat
member.summary: Sets the display of a date and time picker (DTP) control based on a given format string. You can use this macro or send the DTM_SETFORMAT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.
A pointer to a zero-terminated format string that defines the desired display. Setting this parameter to NULL will reset the control to the default format string for the current style.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_SetMonthCalColor
member.summary: Sets the color for a given portion of the month calendar within a date and time picker (DTP) control. You can use this macro or send the DTM_SETMCCOLOR message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.

param.name: iColor
param.para: A value of type int specifying which month calendar color to set. This value can be one of the following:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Set the background color displayed between months.
Set the background color displayed within the month.
Set the color used to display text within a month.
Set the background color displayed in the calendar's title.
Set the color used to display text within the calendar's title.
Set the color used to display header day and trailing day text. Header and trailing days are the days from the previous and following months that appear on the current month calendar.

member.param: A COLORREF value that represents the color that will be set for the specified area of the month calendar.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_SetMonthCalFont
member.summary: Sets the font to be used by the date and time picker (DTP) control's child month calendar control. You can use this macro or explicitly send the DTM_SETMCFONT message.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.
A handle to the font that will be set.
Specifies whether the control should be redrawn immediately upon setting the font. Setting this parameter to TRUE causes the control to redraw itself.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_SetMonthCalStyle
member.summary: Sets the style for a specified date and time picker (DTP) control. Use this macro or send the DTM_SETMCSTYLE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the DTP.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_SetRange
member.summary: Sets the minimum and maximum allowable system times for a date and time picker (DTP) control. You can use this macro or send the DTM_SETRANGE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.

param.name: gd
param.para: A value that specifies which range values are valid. This value can be a combination of the following:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
The first element in the structure array is valid and will be used to set the minimum allowable system time.
The second element in the structure array is valid and will be used to set the maximum allowable system time.

member.param: A pointer to a two-element array of structures. The first element of the SYSTEMTIME array contains the minimum allowable time. The second element of the SYSTEMTIME array contains the maximum allowable time. It is not necessary to fill an array element that is not specified in the flags parameter.

member.name: Windows.DateTime_SetSystemtime
member.summary: Sets a date and time picker (DTP) control to a given date and time. You can use this macro or send the DTM_SETSYSTEMTIME message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a DTP control.

param.name: gd
param.para: A value that specifies the action that should be performed. This should be set to one of the following values.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Set the DTP control according to the data within the structure pointed to by lpSysTime.
Set the DTP control to "no date" and clear its check box. When this flag is specified, lpSysTime is ignored. This flag applies only to DTP controls that are set to the DTS_SHOWNONE style.

member.param: A pointer to a structure that contains the system time information by which to set the DTP control.

member.name: Windows.DefSubclassProc
member.summary: Calls the next handler in a window's subclass chain. The last handler in the subclass chain calls the original window procedure for the window.
member.param: A handle to the window being subclassed.
A value of type unsigned int that specifies a window message.
Specifies additional message information. The contents of this parameter depend on the value of the window message.
Specifies additional message information. The contents of this parameter depend on the value of the window message. Note: On 64-bit versions of Windows LPARAM is a 64-bit value.
member.returns: The returned value is specific to the message sent. This value should be ignored.

member.name: Windows.DrawStatusText
member.summary: The DrawStatusText function draws the specified text in the style of a status window with borders.

Pointer to a structure that contains the position, in client coordinates, of the rectangle in which the text is drawn. The function draws the borders just inside the edges of the specified rectangle.
Pointer to a null-terminated string that specifies the text to display. Tab characters in the string determine whether the string is left-aligned, right-aligned, or centered.

param.para: Text drawing flags. This parameter can be a combination of these values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning

Draws highlighted borders that make the text stand out.
Indicates that the string pointed to by pszText will be displayed in the opposite direction to the text in the parent window.

member.name: Windows.FlatSB_GetScrollProp
member.summary: Gets the properties for a flat scroll bar. This function can also be used to determine if has been called for this window.
member.param: A handle to the window that contains the flat scroll bar. This window handle must have been passed previously in a call to .

param.name: propIndex
param.para: The parameter that determines whatpValue represents and which property is being retrieved. It can be one of the following values.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
pValue is a pointer to an INT value that receives the width, in pixels, of the direction buttons in a horizontal scroll bar.
pValue is a pointer to an INT value that receives the width, in pixels, of the thumb in a horizontal scroll bar.
pValue a pointer to an INT value that receives the width, in pixels, of a vertical scroll bar.
pValue is a pointer to an INT value that receives the height, in pixels, of a horizontal scroll bar.
pValue is a pointer to an INT value that receives the height, in pixels, of the direction buttons in a vertical scroll bar.
pValue is a pointer to an INT value that receives the height, in pixels, of the thumb in a vertical scroll bar.
pValue is a pointer to a COLORREF value that receives the background color in a horizontal scroll bar.

pValue is a pointer to an INT value that receives one of the following visual effects for the horizontal scroll bar. FSB_ENCARTA_MODEA standard flat scroll bar is displayed. When the mouse moves over a direction button or the thumb, that portion of the scroll bar is displayed in 3-D.FSB_FLAT_MODEA standard flat scroll bar is displayed. When the mouse moves over a direction button or the thumb, that portion of the scroll bar is displayed in inverted colors.FSB_REGULAR_MODEA normal, nonflat scroll bar is displayed. No special visual effects are applied.
pValue is a pointer to an HPALETTE value that receives the palette that a scroll bar uses when drawing.
pValue is a pointer to a COLORREF value that receives the background color in a vertical scroll bar.

pValue is a pointer to an INT value that receives one of the following visual effects for the vertical scroll bar. FSB_ENCARTA_MODEA standard flat scroll bar is displayed. When the mouse moves over a direction button or the thumb, that portion of the scroll bar is displayed in 3-D.FSB_FLAT_MODEA standard flat scroll bar is displayed. When the mouse moves over a direction button or the thumb, that portion of the scroll bar is displayed in inverted colors.FSB_REGULAR_MODEA normal, nonflat scroll bar is displayed. No special visual effects are applied.
pValue is a pointer to an INT value that receives the WS_HSCROLL and WS_VSCROLL style bits contained by the current window.

member.param: A pointer to an int that receives the requested data. This parameter depends on the flag passed inindex.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise. Ifindex is WSB_PROP_HSTYLE, the return is nonzero if has been called for this window, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.Header_InsertItem

member.param: A handle to the header control.

The index of the item after which the new item is to be inserted. The new item is inserted at the end of the header control ifindex is greater than or equal to the number of items in the control. Ifindex is zero, the new item is inserted at the beginning of the header control.
A pointer to an structure that contains information about the new item.

member.name: Windows.Header_Layout
member.summary: Retrieves the correct size and position of a header control within the parent window. You can use this macro or send the HDM_LAYOUT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the header control.
A pointer to an structure. Theprc member specifies the coordinates of a rectangle, and thepwpos member receives the size and position for the header control within the rectangle.

member.name: Windows.Header_OrderToIndex
member.summary: Retrieves an index value for an item based on its order in the header control. You can use this macro or send the HDM_ORDERTOINDEX message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a header control.
The order that the item appears within the header control, from left to right. The index value of the item in the far left column would be 0, the next item to the right would be 1, and so on.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetBitmapMargin
member.summary: Sets the width of the margin for a bitmap in an existing header control. You can use this macro or send the HDM_SETBITMAPMARGIN message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a header control.
The width, specified in pixels, of the margin that surrounds a bitmap within an existing header control.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetFilterChangeTimeout
member.summary: Sets the timeout interval between the time a change takes place in the filter attributes and the posting of an HDN_FILTERCHANGE notification. You can use this macro or send the HDM_SETFILTERCHANGETIMEOUT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the header control.
The timeout value, in milliseconds.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetFocusedItem
member.summary: Sets the focus to a specified item in a header control. Use this macro or send the HDM_SETFOCUSEDITEM message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the header control.
The index of item.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetHotDivider
member.summary: Changes the color of a divider between header items to indicate the destination of an external drag-and-drop operation. You can use this macro or send the HDM_SETHOTDIVIDER message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a header control.

param.name: fPos
param.para: A value specifying howdwInputValue is to be interpreted. The value in this field can be one of the following:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Indicates that dwInputValue holds client coordinates of the pointer.
Indicates that dwInputValue holds a divider index value.

param.name: dw
param.para: The value held here is interpreted depending on the value offlag.

Ifflag is TRUE,dwInputValue represents the x- and y- client coordinates of the pointer. The x-coordinate is in the low word, and the y-coordinate is in the high word. Upon receiving the message, the header control highlights the appropriate divider based on thedwInputValue coordinates.
Ifflag is FALSE,dwInputValue represents the integer index of the divider that will be highlighted.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetImageList
member.summary: Assigns an image list to an existing header control. You can use this macro or send the HDM_SETIMAGELIST message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a header control.
A handle to an image list.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetItem
member.summary: Sets the attributes of the specified item in a header control. You can use this macro or send the HDM_SETITEM message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a header control.
The current index of the item whose attributes are to be changed.
A pointer to an structure that contains item information. When this message is sent, themask member of the structure must be set to indicate which attributes are being set.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetOrderArray
member.summary: Sets the left-to-right order of header items. You can use this macro or send the HDM_SETORDERARRAY message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a header control.
The size of the buffer atlpiArray, in elements. This value must equal the value returned by HDM_GETITEMCOUNT.

A pointer to an array that specifies the order in which items should be displayed, from left to right. For example, if the contents of the array are {2,0,1}, the control displays item 2, item 0, and item 1, from left to right.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetStateImageList
member.summary: Assigns an image list to an existing header control state.
member.param: A handle to a header control.
A handle to an image list control.

member.name: Windows.Header_SetUnicodeFormat
member.summary: Sets the UNICODE character format flag for the control. This message allows you to change the character set used by the control at run time rather than having to re-create the control. You can use this macro or send the HDM_SETUNICODEFORMAT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the control.
Determines the character set that is used by the control. If this value is nonzero, the control will use Unicode characters. If this value is zero, the control will use ANSI characters.

member.name: Windows.HIMAGELIST_QueryInterface
member.summary: Retrieves a pointer to an or object that corresponds to the image list's HIMAGELIST handle.
member.param: The handle to the image list.
The identifier of the interface being requested. Normally IID_IImageList or IID_IImageList2.
When this method returns, contains the address of the interface pointer requested in riid. If the object does not support the interface specified in riid, ppv is NULL.
member.returns: If this function succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Add
member.summary: Adds an image or images to an image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
A handle to the bitmap that contains the image or images. The number of images is inferred from the width of the bitmap.
A handle to the bitmap that contains the mask. If no mask is used with the image list, this parameter is ignored. This parameter can be NULL.
member.returns: Returns the index of the first new image if successful, or -1 otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_AddIcon
member.summary: Adds an icon or cursor to an image list. ImageList_AddIcon calls the function.
member.param: A handle to the image list. If this parameter identifies a masked image list, the macro copies both the image and mask bitmaps of the icon or cursor. If this parameter identifies a nonmasked image list, the macro copies only the image bitmap.
A handle to the icon or cursor that contains the bitmap and mask for the new image.
member.returns: Returns the index of the image if successful, or -1 otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_AddMasked
member.summary: Adds an image or images to an image list, generating a mask from the specified bitmap.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
A handle to the bitmap that contains one or more images. The number of images is inferred from the width of the bitmap.

The color used to generate the mask. Each pixel of this color in the specified bitmap is changed to black, and the corresponding bit in the mask is set to 1. If this parameter is CLR_DEFAULT, then the color of the pixel at (0,0) is used as the mask.
member.returns: Returns the index of the first new image if successful, or -1 otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_BeginDrag
member.summary: Begins dragging an image.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
The index of the image to drag.
The x-coordinate of the location of the drag position relative to the upper-left corner of the image.
The y-coordinate of the location of the drag position relative to the upper-left corner of the image.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Copy
member.summary: Copies images within a given image list.
member.param: A handle to an image list that is the target of the copy operation. In current versions of Windows, both himlDst and himlSrc must be identical.
The zero-based index of the image to be used as the destination of the copy operation.
A handle to an image list that is the target of the copy operation. In current versions of Windows, both himlDst and himlSrc must be identical.
The zero-based index of the image to be used as the source of the copy operation.

param.name: uFlags
param.para: the bit flag value that specifies the type of copy operation to be made. This parameter can be one of the following values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
The source image is copied to the destination image's index. This operation results in multiple instances of a given image.
The source and destination images exchange positions within the image list.

member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Create
member.summary: Creates a new image list.
member.param: The width, in pixels, of each image.
The height, in pixels, of each image.
A set of bit flags that specify the type of image list to create. This parameter can be a combination of the Image List Creation Flags.
The number of images that the image list initially contains.
The number of images by which the image list can grow when the system needs to make room for new images. This parameter represents the number of new images that the resized image list can contain.
member.returns: Returns the handle to the image list if successful, or NULL otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Destroy
member.summary: Destroys an image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list to destroy.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_DragEnter
member.summary: Displays the drag image at the specified position within the window.
member.param: A handle to the window that owns the drag image.
The x-coordinate at which to display the drag image. The coordinate is relative to the upper-left corner of the window, not the client area.
The y-coordinate at which to display the drag image. The coordinate is relative to the upper-left corner of the window, not the client area.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_DragLeave
member.summary: Unlocks the specified window and hides the drag image, allowing the window to be updated.
member.param: A handle to the window that owns the drag image.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_DragMove
member.summary: Moves the image that is being dragged during a drag-and-drop operation. This function is typically called in response to a WM_MOUSEMOVE message.
member.param: The x-coordinate at which to display the drag image. The coordinate is relative to the upper-left corner of the window, not the client area.
The y-coordinate at which to display the drag image. The coordinate is relative to the upper-left corner of the window, not the client area.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_DragShowNolock
member.summary: Shows or hides the image being dragged.
member.param: A value specifying whether to show or hide the image being dragged. Specify TRUE to show the image or FALSE to hide the image.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Draw
member.summary: Draws an image list item in the specified device context.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
The zero-based index of the image to draw.
A handle to the destination device context.
The x-coordinate at which to draw within the specified device context.
The y-coordinate at which to draw within the specified device context.

param.name: fStyle
param.para: The drawing style and, optionally, the overlay image. For information about specifying an overlay image index, see the comments section at the end of this topic. This parameter can be a combination of an overlay image index and one or more of the following values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Draws the image, blending 25 percent with the system highlight color. This value has no effect if the image list does not contain a mask.
Draws the image, blending 50 percent with the system highlight color. This value has no effect if the image list does not contain a mask.
Set this flag if the overlay does not require a mask to be drawn. This flag causes to draw just the image, ignoring the mask.
Draws the mask.
Draws the image using the background color for the image list. If the background color is the CLR_NONE value, the image is drawn transparently using the mask.
Draws the image transparently using the mask, regardless of the background color. This value has no effect if the image list does not contain a mask.

member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_DrawEx
member.summary: Draws an image list item in the specified device context. The function uses the specified drawing style and blends the image with the specified color.
member.param: A handle to the image list
The index of the image to draw.
A handle to the destination device context.
The x-coordinate at which to draw within the specified device context.
The y-coordinate at which to draw within the specified device context.

The width of the portion of the image to draw relative to the upper-left corner of the image. If dx anddy are zero, the function draws the entire image. The function does not ensure that the parameters are valid.

The height of the portion of the image to draw, relative to the upper-left corner of the image. Ifdx anddy are zero, the function draws the entire image. The function does not ensure that the parameters are valid.

param.name: rgbBk
param.para: The background color of the image. This parameter can be an application-defined RGB value or one of the following values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
No background color. The image is drawn transparently.
The default background color. The image is drawn using the background color of the image list.

param.name: rgbFg
param.para: The foreground color of the image. This parameter can be an application-defined RGB value or one of the following values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
No blend color. The image is blended with the color of the destination device context.
The default foreground color. The image is drawn using the system highlight color as the foreground color.

param.name: fStyle
param.para: The drawing style and, optionally, the overlay image. For information about specifying an overlay image index, see the comments section at the end of this topic. This parameter can be a combination of an overlay image index and one or more of the following values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Draws the image, blending 25 percent with the blend color specified by rgbFg. This value has no effect if the image list does not contain a mask.
Draws the image, blending 50 percent with the blend color specified by rgbFg. This value has no effect if the image list does not contain a mask.
Set this flag if the overlay does not require a mask to be drawn. This flag causes ImageList_DrawEx to draw just the image, ignoring the mask.
Draws the mask.
Draws the image using the background color for the image list. If the background color is the CLR_NONE value, the image is drawn transparently using the mask.
Draws the image transparently using the mask, regardless of the background color. This value has no effect if the image list does not contain a mask.

member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_DrawIndirect
member.summary: Draws an image list image based on an structure.
member.param: A pointer to an structure that contains information about the draw operation.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, and zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Duplicate
member.summary: Creates a duplicate of an existing image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list to be duplicated. All information contained in the original image list for normal images is copied to the new image list. Overlay images are not copied.
member.returns: Returns the handle to the new duplicate image list if successful, or NULL otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_EndDrag
member.summary: Ends a drag operation.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_ExtractIcon
member.summary: Calls the function to create an icon or cursor based on an image and mask in an image list.
member.param: This parameter is not used and should always be zero.
A handle to the image list.
The index of the image.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_GetBkColor
member.summary: Retrieves the current background color for an image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
member.returns: The return value is the background color.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_GetDragImage
member.summary: Retrieves the temporary image list that is used for the drag image. The function also retrieves the current drag position and the offset of the drag image relative to the drag position.
member.param: A pointer to a structure that receives the current drag position. Can be NULL.
A pointer to a POINT structure that receives the offset of the drag image relative to the drag position. Can be NULL.
member.returns: Returns the handle to the image list if successful, or NULL otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_GetIcon
member.summary: Creates an icon from an image and mask in an image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
An index of the image.
A combination of flags that specify the drawing style. For a list of values, see the description of the fStyle parameter of the function.
member.returns: Returns the handle to the icon if successful, or NULL otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_GetIconSize
member.summary: Retrieves the dimensions of images in an image list. All images in an image list have the same dimensions.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
A pointer to an integer variable that receives the width, in pixels, of each image.
A pointer to an integer variable that receives the height, in pixels, of each image.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_GetImageCount
member.summary: Retrieves the number of images in an image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
member.returns: Returns the number of images.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_GetImageInfo
member.summary: Retrieves information about an image.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
The index of the image.
A pointer to an structure that receives information about the image. The information in this structure can be used to directly manipulate the bitmaps for the image.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_LoadBitmap
member.summary: Calls the function to create an image list from the specified bitmap resource.
member.param: A handle to the instance that contains the bitmap resource. This parameter is NULL if you are loading an OEM bitmap.

The image to load. If the hi parameter is non-NULL, lpbmp is the address of a null-terminated string that contains the name of the image resource in the hi module. If hi is NULL, the LOWORD of this parameter must be the identifier of an OEM bitmap to load. To create this value, use the macro with one of the OEM bitmap identifiers defined in WINUSER.H. These identifiers have the OBM_ prefix.
The width of each image. The height of each image and the initial number of images are inferred by the dimensions of the specified bitmap.
The number of images by which the image list can grow when the system needs to make room for new images. This parameter represents the number of new images that the resized image list can contain.

The color used to generate a mask. Each pixel of this color in the specified bitmap is changed to black, and the corresponding bit in the mask is set to 1. If this parameter is the CLR_NONE value, no mask is generated.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_LoadImage
member.summary: Creates an image list from the specified bitmap.
member.param: A handle to the instance that contains the resource. This parameter can be NULL if you are loading an image from a file or loading an OEM resource.

param.name: lpbmp
param.para: The image to load.
If the uFlags parameter includes LR_LOADFROMFILE, lpbmp is the address of a null-terminated string that names the file containing the image to load.
If the hi parameter is non-NULL and LR_LOADFROMFILE is not specified, lpbmp is the address of a null-terminated string that contains the name of the image resource in the hi module.

If hi is NULL and LR_LOADFROMFILE is not specified, the LOWORD of this parameter must be the identifier of an OEM image to load. To create this value, use the macro with one of the OEM image identifiers defined in Winuser.h. These identifiers have the following prefixes.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning

member.param: The width of each image. The height of each image and the initial number of images are inferred by the dimensions of the specified resource.
The number of images by which the image list can grow when the system needs to make room for new images. This parameter represents the number of new images that the resized image list can contain.

The color used to generate a mask. Each pixel of this color in the specified bitmap, cursor, or icon is changed to black, and the corresponding bit in the mask is set to 1. If this parameter is the CLR_NONE value, no mask is generated. If this parameter is the CLR_DEFAULT value, the color of the pixel at the upper-left corner of the image is treated as the mask color.

param.name: uType
param.para: A flag that specifies the type of image to load. This parameter must be IMAGE_BITMAP to indicate that a bitmap is being loaded.
param.div: Note ImageList_LoadImage is for use only with bitmap files. No other image types are supported.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Loads a bitmap.

param.name: uFlags
param.para: Flags that specify how to load the image. This parameter can be a combination of the following values.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning

Causes the function to return a DIB section bitmap rather than a compatible bitmap when the uType parameter specifies IMAGE_BITMAP. LR_CREATEDIBSECTION is useful for loading a bitmap without mapping it to the colors of the display device.
Uses the color format of the display.

Uses the width or height specified by the system metric values for cursors and icons if the cx parameter is set to zero. If this value is not specified and cx is set to zero, the function sets the size to the one specified in the resource. If the resource contains multiple images, the function sets the size to that of the first image.
Loads the image from the file specified by the lpbmp parameter.

Searches the color table for the image and replaces the following shades of gray with the corresponding three-dimensional color:
Dk Gray: RGB(128, 128, 128)COLOR_3DSHADOW
Gray: RGB(192, 192, 192)COLOR_3DFACE
Lt Gray: RGB(223, 223, 223)COLOR_3DLIGHT
For more information, see the Remarks section.

Retrieves the color value of the first pixel in the image and replaces the corresponding entry in the color table with the default window color (the COLOR_WINDOW display color). All pixels in the image that use that color become the default window value color. This value applies only to images that have a corresponding color table. For more information, see the Remarks section.
Loads the image in black and white.

Shares the image handle if the image is loaded multiple times. Do not use this value for images that have nontraditional sizes that might change after loading or for images that are loaded from a file.

member.returns: Returns the handle to the image list if successful, or NULL otherwise.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning

member.param: The width of each image. The height of each image and the initial number of images are inferred by the dimensions of the specified resource.
The number of images by which the image list can grow when the system needs to make room for new images. This parameter represents the number of new images that the resized image list can contain.

The color used to generate a mask. Each pixel of this color in the specified bitmap, cursor, or icon is changed to black, and the corresponding bit in the mask is set to 1. If this parameter is the CLR_NONE value, no mask is generated. If this parameter is the CLR_DEFAULT value, the color of the pixel at the upper-left corner of the image is treated as the mask color.

param.name: uType
param.para: A flag that specifies the type of image to load. This parameter must be IMAGE_BITMAP to indicate that a bitmap is being loaded.
param.div: Note ImageList_LoadImage is for use only with bitmap files. No other image types are supported.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Loads a bitmap.

param.name: uFlags
param.para: Flags that specify how to load the image. This parameter can be a combination of the following values.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning

Causes the function to return a DIB section bitmap rather than a compatible bitmap when the uType parameter specifies IMAGE_BITMAP. LR_CREATEDIBSECTION is useful for loading a bitmap without mapping it to the colors of the display device.
Uses the color format of the display.

Uses the width or height specified by the system metric values for cursors and icons if the cx parameter is set to zero. If this value is not specified and cx is set to zero, the function sets the size to the one specified in the resource. If the resource contains multiple images, the function sets the size to that of the first image.
Loads the image from the file specified by the lpbmp parameter.

Searches the color table for the image and replaces the following shades of gray with the corresponding three-dimensional color:
Dk Gray: RGB(128, 128, 128)COLOR_3DSHADOW
Gray: RGB(192, 192, 192)COLOR_3DFACE
Lt Gray: RGB(223, 223, 223)COLOR_3DLIGHT
For more information, see the Remarks section.

Retrieves the color value of the first pixel in the image and replaces the corresponding entry in the color table with the default window color (the COLOR_WINDOW display color). All pixels in the image that use that color become the default window value color. This value applies only to images that have a corresponding color table. For more information, see the Remarks section.
Loads the image in black and white.

Shares the image handle if the image is loaded multiple times. Do not use this value for images that have nontraditional sizes that might change after loading or for images that are loaded from a file.

member.returns: Returns the handle to the image list if successful, or NULL otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_LoadImageA
member.summary: Creates an image list from the specified bitmap.
member.param: A handle to the instance that contains the resource. This parameter can be NULL if you are loading an image from a file or loading an OEM resource.

param.name: lpbmp
param.para: The image to load.
If the uFlags parameter includes LR_LOADFROMFILE, lpbmp is the address of a null-terminated string that names the file containing the image to load.
If the hi parameter is non-NULL and LR_LOADFROMFILE is not specified, lpbmp is the address of a null-terminated string that contains the name of the image resource in the hi module.

If hi is NULL and LR_LOADFROMFILE is not specified, the LOWORD of this parameter must be the identifier of an OEM image to load. To create this value, use the macro with one of the OEM image identifiers defined in Winuser.h. These identifiers have the following prefixes.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Merge
member.summary: Creates a new image by combining two existing images. The function also creates a new image list in which to store the image.
member.param: A handle to the first image list.
The index of the first existing image.
A handle to the second image list.
The index of the second existing image.
The x-offset of the second image relative to the first image.
The y-offset of the second image relative to the first image.
member.returns: Returns the handle to the new image list if successful, or NULL otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Read
member.summary: Reads an image list from a stream.
member.param: A pointer to the stream.
member.returns: Returns the handle to the image list if successful, or NULL otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_ReadEx
member.summary: Reads an image list from a stream, and returns an interface to the image list.

param.name: dwFlags
param.para: A flag that specifies how the stream is read.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Expects an image list that was written with the ILP_NORMAL flag specified.
Expects an image list that was written with the ILP_DOWNLEVEL flag specified.

member.param: The address of the stream.
An IID for the image list.
The address of a pointer to the interface for the image list if successful, NULL otherwise.
member.returns: If this function succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Remove
member.summary: Removes an image from an image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
The index of the image to remove. If this parameter is -1, the function removes all images.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_RemoveAll
member.summary: Calls the function to remove all of the images from an image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Replace
member.summary: Replaces an image in an image list with a new image.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
An index of the image to replace.
A handle to the bitmap that contains the image.
A handle to the bitmap that contains the mask. If no mask is used with the image list, this parameter is ignored.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_ReplaceIcon
member.summary: Replaces an image with an icon or cursor.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
The index of the image to replace. Ifi is -1, the function appends the image to the end of the list.
The handle to the icon or cursor that contains the bitmap and mask for the new image.
member.returns: Returns the index of the image if successful, or -1 otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_SetBkColor
member.summary: Sets the background color for an image list. This function only works if you add an icon or use with a black and white bitmap. Without a mask, the entire image is drawn; hence the background color is not visible.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
The background color to set. This parameter can be the CLR_NONE value; in that case, images are drawn transparently using the mask.
member.returns: Returns the previous background color if successful, or CLR_NONE otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_SetDragCursorImage
member.summary: Creates a new drag image by combining the specified image (typically a mouse cursor image) with the current drag image.
member.param: A handle to the image list that contains the new image to combine with the drag image.
The index of the new image to combine with the drag image.
The x-position of the hot spot within the new image.
The y-position of the hot spot within the new image.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_SetIconSize
member.summary: Sets the dimensions of images in an image list and removes all images from the list.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
The width, in pixels, of the images in the image list. All images in an image list have the same dimensions.
The height, in pixels, of the images in the image list. All images in an image list have the same dimensions.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_SetImageCount
member.summary: Resizes an existing image list.
member.param: A handle to the image list that will be resized.
A value specifying the new size of the image list.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_SetOverlayImage
member.summary: Adds a specified image to the list of images to be used as overlay masks. An image list can have up to four overlay masks in version 4.70 and earlier and up to 15 in version 4.71. The function assigns an overlay mask index to the specified image.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
The zero-based index of an image in the himl image list. This index identifies the image to use as an overlay mask.
The one-based index of the overlay mask.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_Write
member.summary: Writes an image list to a stream.
member.param: A handle to the image list.
A pointer to the stream.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ImageList_WriteEx
member.summary: Writes an image list to a stream.
member.param: A handle to the image list.

param.name: dwFlags
param.para: A flag that specifies how the stream is written.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Writes to the stream using the file format for Common Controls 6.0, which includes information about image list attributes new to this version.
Writes to the stream using a file format previous to version 6.0. Specify this flag if you need to save image lists loaded under Common Controls versions earlier than version 6.0.

member.param: The address of the stream.
member.returns: If this function succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

member.name: Windows.INDEXTOOVERLAYMASK
member.summary: Prepares the index of an overlay mask so that the function can use it.
member.param: An index of an overlay mask.

member.name: Windows.INDEXTOSTATEIMAGEMASK
member.summary: Prepares the index of a state image so that a tree-view control or list-view control can use the index to retrieve the state image for an item.
member.param: The index of a state image.

member.name: Windows.InitCommonControls
member.summary: Registers and initializes certain common control window classes. This function is obsolete. New applications should use the function.

member.name: Windows.InitCommonControlsEx
member.summary: Ensures that the common control DLL (Comctl32.dll) is loaded, and registers specific common control classes from the DLL. An application must call this function before creating a common control.
member.param: A pointer to an structure that contains information specifying which control classes will be registered.
member.returns: Returns TRUE if successful, or FALSE otherwise.

member.name: Windows.InitializeFlatSB
member.summary: Initializes flat scroll bars for a particular window.
member.param: A handle to the window that will receive flat scroll bars.
member.returns: Returns nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.

member.name: Windows.InitMUILanguage
member.summary: Enables an application to specify a language to be used with the common controls that is different from the system language.
member.param: The language identifier of the language to be used by the common controls.

member.name: Windows.LBItemFromPt
member.summary: Retrieves the index of the item at the specified point in a list box.
member.param: A handle to the list box to check.
A structure that contains the screen coordinates to check.

A scroll flag. If this parameter is TRUE and the point is directly above or below the list box, the function scrolls the list box by one line and returns -1. Otherwise, the function does not scroll the list box.
member.returns: Returns the item identifier if the point is over a list item, or -1 otherwise.

member.name: Windows.ListView_ApproximateViewRect
member.summary: Calculates the approximate width and height required to display a given number of items. You can use this macro or send the LVM_APPROXIMATEVIEWRECT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The proposed x-dimension of the control, in pixels. This parameter can be -1 to allow the message to use the current width value.
The proposed y-dimension of the control, in pixels. This parameter can be -1 to allow the message to use the current height value.
The number of items to be displayed in the control. If this parameter is -1, the message uses the total number of items in the control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_Arrange
member.summary: Arranges items in icon view. You can use this macro or send the LVM_ARRANGE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

param.name: code
param.para: One of the following values that specifies alignment:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Not implemented. Apply the LVS_ALIGNLEFT style instead.
Not implemented. Apply the LVS_ALIGNTOP style instead.
Aligns items according to the list-view control's current alignment styles (the default value).
Snaps all icons to the nearest grid position.

member.name: Windows.ListView_CancelEditLabel
member.summary: Cancels an item text editing operation. You can use this macro or send the LVM_CANCELEDITLABEL message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_CreateDragImage
member.summary: Creates a drag image list for the specified item. You can use this macro or send the LVM_CREATEDRAGIMAGE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the item.
A pointer to a structure that receives the initial location of the upper-left corner of the image, in view coordinates.

member.name: Windows.ListView_DeleteAllItems

member.name: Windows.ListView_DeleteColumn
member.summary: Removes a column from a list-view control. You can use this macro or send the LVM_DELETECOLUMN message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
An index of the column to delete.

member.name: Windows.ListView_DeleteItem
member.summary: Removes an item from a list-view control. You can use this macro or send the LVM_DELETEITEM message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
An index of the list-view item to delete.

member.name: Windows.ListView_EditLabel
member.summary: Begins in-place editing of the specified list-view item's text. The message implicitly selects and focuses the specified item. You can use this macro or send the LVM_EDITLABEL message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the list-view item. To cancel editing, setiItem to -1.

member.name: Windows.ListView_EnableGroupView
member.summary: Enables or disables whether the items in a list-view control display as a group. You can use this macro or send the LVM_ENABLEGROUPVIEW message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_EnsureVisible
member.summary: Ensures that a list-view item is either entirely or partially visible, scrolling the list-view control if necessary. You can use this macro or send the LVM_ENSUREVISIBLE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the list-view item.
A value specifying whether the item must be entirely visible. If this parameter is TRUE, no scrolling occurs if the item is at least partially visible.

member.name: Windows.ListView_FindItem
member.summary: Searches for a list-view item with the specified characteristics. You can use this macro or send the LVM_FINDITEM message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the item after which to begin the search, or -1 to start from the beginning.
A pointer to an structure that contains information about what to search for.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetBkColor
member.summary: Gets the background color of a list-view control. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETBKCOLOR message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetBkImage
member.summary: Gets the background image in a list-view control. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETBKIMAGE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
A pointer to a structure that will receive the background image information.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetCallbackMask
member.summary: Gets the callback mask for a list-view control. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETCALLBACKMASK message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetCheckState
member.summary: Determines if an item in a list-view control is selected. This should be used only for list-view controls that have the LVS_EX_CHECKBOXES style.
member.param: A handle to a list-view control.
The index of the item for which to retrieve the check state.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetColumn
member.summary: Gets the attributes of a list-view control's column. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETCOLUMN message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the column.

A pointer to an structure that specifies the information to retrieve and receives information about the column. Themask member specifies which column attributes to retrieve. If the mask member specifies the LVCF_TEXT value, the pszText member must contain the address of the buffer that receives the item text, and the cchTextMax member must specify the size of the buffer.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetColumnOrderArray
member.summary: Gets the current left-to-right order of columns in a list-view control. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETCOLUMNORDERARRAY message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to a list-view control.
The number of columns in the list-view control.
A pointer to an array of integers that will receive the index values of the columns in the list-view control. The array must be large enough to holdiCount elements.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetColumnWidth
member.summary: Gets the width of a column in report or list view. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETCOLUMNWIDTH message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the column. This parameter is ignored in list view.

member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetEditControl
member.summary: Gets the handle to the edit control being used to edit a list-view item's text. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETEDITCONTROL message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetEmptyText
member.summary: Gets the text meant for display when the list-view control appears empty. Use this macro or send the LVM_GETEMPTYTEXT message explicitly.

The size of the buffer pointed to by pszText, including the terminating NULL.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetExtendedListViewStyle
member.summary: Gets the extended styles that are currently in use for a given list-view control. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETEXTENDEDLISTVIEWSTYLE message explicitly.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetFocusedGroup
member.summary: Gets the group that has the focus. Use this macro or send the LVM_GETFOCUSEDGROUP message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetFooterInfo

member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
A pointer to a structure to receive information depending on the value of the mask member. The calling application is responsible for allocating this structure and setting the mask member.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetFooterItem
member.summary: Gets information on a footer item for a specified list-view control. Use this macro or send the LVM_GETFOOTERITEM message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
An index of the item.

A pointer to a structure to receive a value for the state and/or pszText members according to the value of the mask member. The caller is responsible for allocating this structure and setting its members to indicate to the receiver what information to return. For more information, see LVFOOTERITEM.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetFooterItemRect
member.summary: Gets the coordinates of a footer for a specified item in a list-view control. Use this macro or send the LVM_GETFOOTERITEMRECT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetGroupCount
member.summary: Gets the number of groups. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETGROUPCOUNT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetGroupHeaderImageList
member.summary: Gets the group header image list that has been set for an existing list-view control.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetGroupInfo
member.summary: Gets group information. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETGROUPINFO message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetGroupInfoByIndex
member.summary: Gets information on a specified group. Use this macro or send the LVM_GETGROUPINFOBYINDEX message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the group.

param.name: pgrp
param.para: A pointer to an structure to receive information on the group specified by iIndex. The calling application is responsible for allocating memory for the structure and any buffers in the structure, such as, the one pointed to by pszHeader. Set any contingent members of the structure, such as, cchHeader—the size of the buffer pointed to by pszHeader in WCHARs, including the terminating NULL. Set cbSize to the size of LVGROUP in bytes.
The message receiver is responsible for setting the structure members with information for the group specified by iIndex.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetGroupMetrics
member.summary: Gets information about the display of groups. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETGROUPMETRICS message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetGroupRect
member.summary: Gets the rectangle for a specified group. Use this macro or send the LVM_GETGROUPRECT message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
Specifies the group by iGroupId (see structure).

param.name: type
param.para: Specifies the type of rectangle to retrieve. This parameter must be one of the following values.

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Coordinates of the entire expanded group.
Coordinates of the header only (collapsed group).
Coordinates of the label only.

Coordinates of the subset link only (markup subset). A list-view control can limit the number of visible items displayed in each group. A link is presented to the user to allow the user to expand the group. This flag will return the bounding rectangle of the subset link if the group is a subset (group state of LVGS_SUBSETED, see structure , member state). This flag is provided so that accessibility applications can locate the link.

member.param: A pointer to a structure to receive information on the group specified by iGroupId. The message receiver is responsible for setting the structure members with information for the group specified by iGroupId. The calling application is responsible for allocating memory for the structure.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetGroupState
member.summary: Gets the state for a specified group. Use this macro or send the LVM_GETGROUPSTATE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
Specifies the group by iGroupId (see structure).

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetNextItem
member.summary: Searches for a list-view item that has the specified properties and bears the specified relationship to a specified item. You can use this macro or send the LVM_GETNEXTITEM message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the item with which to begin the search, or -1 to find the first item that matches the specified flags. The specified item itself is excluded from the search.

The geometric relation of the requested item to the specified item and, if specified, the state of the requested item. For a list of possible values, see the description of thelParam parameter in the LVM_GETNEXTITEM message. If an item does not have all of the specified state flags set, the search continues with the next item.

member.name: Windows.ListView_GetNextItemIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the item in a particular list-view control that has the specified properties and relationship to another specific item. Use this macro or send the LVM_GETNEXTITEMINDEX message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.

A pointer to the structure with which the item begins the search, or -1 to find the first item that matches the specified flags. The calling process is responsible for allocating this structure and setting its members.

param.name: flags
param.para: The relationship to the item specified in parameterplvii. This can be one or a combination of the following values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
Searches for a subsequent item by index, the default value.

listheader.term: Searches by physical relationship to the index of the item where the search is to begin.

listheader.description: Searches for an item that is above the specified item.
Searches for an item that is below the specified item.
Searches for an item to the left of the specified item.

Windows Vista and later: Searches for the item that is previous to the specified item. The LVNI_PREVIOUS flag is not directional (LVNI_ABOVE will find the item positioned above, while LVNI_PREVIOUS will find the item ordered before.) The LVNI_PREVIOUS flag essentially reverses the logic of the search performed via the LVM_GETNEXTITEM or LVM_GETNEXTITEMINDEX messages.
Searches for an item to the right of the specified item.
Windows Vista and later: A directional flag mask with value as follows: LVNI_ABOVE | LVNI_BELOW | LVNI_TOLEFT | LVNI_TORIGHT.

listheader.term: The state of the item to find can be specified with one or a combination of the following values:

listheader.description: The item has the LVIS_CUT state flag set.
The item has the LVIS_DROPHILITED state flag set
The item has the LVIS_FOCUSED state flag set.
The item has the LVIS_SELECTED state flag set.
Windows Vista and later: A state flag mask with value as follows: LVNI_FOCUSED | LVNI_SELECTED | LVNI_CUT | LVNI_DROPHILITED.

listheader.term: Searches by appearance of items or by group.

listheader.description: Windows Vista and later: Search the visible order.
Windows Vista and later: Search the visible items.
Windows Vista and later: Search the current group.

listheader.term: If an item does not have all of the specified state flags set, the search continues with the next item.

member.name: Windows.ListView_SetItemState
member.summary: Changes the state of an item in a list-view control. You can use this macro or send the LVM_SETITEMSTATE message explicitly.
member.param: A handle to the list-view control.
The index of the list-view item. If this parameter is -1, then the state change is applied to all items.

param.name: data
param.para: New state bits for the item. The mask parameter indicates the valid bits of the state parameter. The macro ignores bits in the state parameter if the corresponding bit is not set in the mask parameter. The low-order byte contains a set of bit flags that indicate the item's state. This byte can be a combination of the following values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning
The item is marked for a cut-and-paste operation.
The item is highlighted as a drag-and-drop target.
The item has the focus, so it is surrounded by a standard focus rectangle. Although more than one item may be selected, only one item can have the focus.

The item is selected. The appearance of a selected item depends on whether it has the focus and also on the system colors used for selection. Items will only show as selected if the list-view control has focus or the LVS_SHOWSELALWAYS style is used.

member.param: Bits of thestate parameter that you want to set or clear. You can use ListView_SetItemState both to set and to clear bits. To set an item's overlay image index, set the LVIS_OVERLAYMASK bits. To set an item's state image index, set the LVIS_STATEIMAGEMASK bits.

member.name: Windows.LoadIconMetric
member.summary: Loads a specified icon resource with a client-specified system metric.

param.name: hinst
param.para: A handle to the module of either a DLL or executable (.exe) file that contains the icon to be loaded. For more information, see .
To load a predefined system icon or a standalone icon file, set this parameter to NULL.

param.name: pszName
param.para: A pointer to a null-terminated, Unicode buffer that contains location information about the icon to load.

param.name: lims
param.para: The desired metric. One of the following values:

listheader.description: Value
Meaning

member.param: When this function returns, contains a pointer to the handle of the loaded icon.

returns.para: Returns S_OK if successful, otherwise an error, including the following value.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
The contents of the buffer pointed to by pszName do not fit any of the expected interpretations.

DWORD_PTR to reference data. The meaning of this value is determined by the calling application. This value is passed to the subclass procedure in the dwRefData parameter. A different dwRefData is associated with each combination of window handle, subclass procedure and uIdSubclass.
